*This week we dive into programming with R by learning to create visualizations with ggplot2 and learn how to run R code in RStudio.*

- Claus Wilke, [Fundamentals of Data Visualization](https://clauswilke.com/dataviz/) (O'Reilly 2019), Chapters 2 and 5.
- John Theibault, "Visualizations and Historical Arguments," in *Writing History in the Digital Age*, ed. Jack Dougherty and Kristen Nawrotzki (University of Michigan Press, 2013), <https://doi.org/10.3998/dh.12230987.0001.001>, 173â€“185.

## Resources

See Resources pages for RStudio and visualization.

### Working in RStudio
- [Wickham et al., *R for Data Science*](https://r4ds.hadley.nz), chapters 2, 6, and 8.
- [RStudio User Guide](https://docs.posit.co/ide/user/)

### Visualization
Make sure to look at the [ggplot2 website](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org) that is full of great documentation and examples, including a [ggplot2 cheatsheet](https://github.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/blob/main/data-visualization.pdf).

- [The Royal Statistical Society Data visualization Guide](https://royal-statistical-society.github.io/datavisguide/)
- [Wickham et al., *R for Data Science*](https://r4ds.hadley.nz), chapters 1, 9, 10, and 11.
- If you want some inspiration, look at [Nicola Rennie's](https://nrennie.rbind.io) visualization projects.
